event.doc_name: Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

evidence.text: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau was established in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis by the Consumer Financial Protection Act ("CFPA"), which is Title X of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

evidence.text: The enumerated consumer laws, a defined set of consumer financial statutes including the Truth in Lending Act and Equal Credit Opportunity Act, likewise require specific actions by the CFPB.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

evidence.text: The enumerated consumer laws, a defined set of consumer financial statutes including the Truth in Lending Act and Equal Credit Opportunity Act, likewise require specific actions by the CFPB.
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

evidence.text: The Home Mortgage Disclosure Act, for example, requires mortgage lenders to collect and report information about applications for mortgage loans to the CFPB, 12 U.S.C. 2803(h)(1), and directs that the Bureau "shall provide staff and data processing resources" to an interagency body...
evidence.source_document: Complaint for Injunctive and Declaratory Relief

args.reason: All checklist items are fully extracted with 4 distinct statutory bases from the fully visited Complaint document. No further documents contain additional values for this checklist item.

All 4 distinct statutory bases (Consumer Financial Protection Act, Truth in Lending Act, Equal Credit Opportunity Act, Home Mortgage Disclosure Act) were fully extracted from the fully visited Complaint document. No additional values exist in any remaining documents based on the current evidence.
